urls.title: Guest blog - How nature dies by Alistair Gammell - Mark Avery
urls.description: Alistair Gammell worked for RSPB for 40 years and was closely involved in the drafting of the Birds and Habitats Directives and for growing RSPB‚Äôs international work. He was RSPB‚Äôs first International Director and retired from RSPB in 2009. He then worked to successfully establish large scale fully protected marine reserves in the seas around the British Indian Ocean Territory and Pitcairn Island. He is a passionate nature conservationist and fly fisherman (alistairgammell@yahoo.co.uk) Oughton Head is a

The demolition of Shade Chapel, which will help reduce flood risk in Todmorden, has progressed well this weekend. 

The roads will be reopening as planned at 6am tomorrow morning (Monday) with all diversions no longer in place. 

Thanks to residents for their support. https://t.co/auX7LoprCe

@EnvAgency If you are refusing to do a site visit and sample the discharge and you are refusing to accept a sample I have collected, then we need to know who is suitable for collecting a sample and what parameters are acceptable in order to prove pollution is still occurring.

Did you know that there are properties at risk of flooding in #Salisbury? 

We are working with @EnvAgencySW to develop & deliver a transformational plan to reduce flooding, improve biodiversity & green spaces. 

Have your say #SalisburyRiverPark
